docs.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from organ transplant centers and members of Congress, the Clinton Administration said today that it would publish revised regulations aimed at getting organs to the patients who need them most. The Department of Health and Human Services had issued regulations last year directing an overhaul of the nation's transplant system, arguing that patients in some communities unfairly waited much longer than others for a transplant.

headline.main: Agency to Release Rules On Use of Donor Organs

docs.abstract: Clinton Adm, under presure from organ transplant centers and members of Congress, says that it will publish revised regulations aimed at getting organs to patients who need them most; under current system, organs are distributed in local areas first, even if there are sicker patients elsewhere; revised rules discussed (S)
docs.snippet: Under pressure from organ transplant centers and members of Congress, the Clinton Administration said today that it would publish revised regulations aimed at getting organs to the patients who need them most.    The Department of Health and Human...

docs.lead_paragraph: Optimism and a fighting attitude may help breast cancer patients cope with their illnesses, but positive thinking is unlikely to increase their chances of survival, according to a study by British researchers. At the same time, persistent hopelessness, the study found, may raise a woman's risk of suffering a relapse or succumbing to her disease. Of the women who agreed with statements like ''I feel like giving up,'' only 58 percent were alive or in remission five years later, compared with 72 percent who did not report such feelings.

headline.main: 'Fighting Spirit' Little Help in Cancer Fight

docs.abstract: Study by British researchers finds that optimism and a fighting attitude may help breast cancer patients cope with their illnesses, but positive thinking is unlikely to increase their chances of survival (M)
docs.snippet: Optimism and a fighting attitude may help breast cancer patients cope with their illnesses, but positive thinking is unlikely to increase their chances of survival, according to a study by British researchers.    At the same time, persistent...

docs.lead_paragraph: Most mornings, Bob Spina Jr. is up by 5 and out the door before his wife and three daughters are awake. It is still dark, but he gets in a 15-mile run, a 60-mile bike ride or a swim before most of his neighbors in Massapequa are putting filters in their coffee makers. He is back in time to help get the girls ready for school and give his wife, Lori, time to take her own five- or six-mile run. Then it's off to work, as a real-estate and estate lawyer. But the day's workouts are not done: after all, as Mr. Spina says, training for an Ironman triathlon -- a 2.4-mile swim, a 112-mile bike ride and a 26.2-mile run -- is a job in itself.
docs.abstract: Demanding training regimen for Ironman Triathlon in Hawaii described; training schedule of Bob Spina as he prepares for Ironman championship noted; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Although disas ters from hurricanes to earthquakes to political unrest -- can be devastating for anyone, they can be particularly hard on children. But the special health needs of these youngest victims often go unmet, experts say. Children, for example, absorb nutrition in smaller doses than adults, but few relief workers recognize that giving them a single large meal a day, as is sometimes done with adult victims, is insufficient. Children suffering from malnutrition should not be treated with many common drugs, including certain antibiotics, and they need special instruction and supervision in basic hygiene to keep them from getting and spreading infectious disease.

headline.main: Manual Addresses Needs Of Children in Disasters

docs.abstract: Experts say that disasters, from hurricanes to earthquakes to political unrest, can be particularly hard on children, but that special needs of these youngest victims often go unmet; several pediatric health orgns have joined to produce handbook, Helping the Children, and a training program for relief workers who deal with refugees and victims of disasters to help deal with children in these situations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ruth had undergone a mysterious personality change that defied psychiatric explanation. Charles awoke each morning with a severe headache that eased as the day progressed. Kathleen experienced partial facial paralysis, slurred her words and drooled. Marlys suffered a grand mal seizure that rendered her unconscious for about 15 minutes. All four had different kinds of brain tumors. Ruth's was benign and grew slowly, but it was not detected for years, too late for treatment that could have saved her.

headline.main: Brain Tumors: Elusive, Varied and Not Always Deadly

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on brain tumors; notes that for reasons yet to be determined, brain tumors are becoming more common, especially in older people; says that since mid-1980's, yearly total of Americans given diagnoses of brain tumors has doubled, and is expected to exceed 100,000 this year; survival rates, too, have been inching up, thanks to improved diagnostic techniques and more precise and inventive treatments (M)
docs.snippet: Ruth had undergone a mysterious personality change that defied psychiatric explanation. Charles awoke each morning with a severe headache that eased as the day progressed. Kathleen experienced partial facial paralysis, slurred her words and drooled....

docs.lead_paragraph: Frustrated by the continued spread of H.I.V., a growing number of AIDS doctors are trying out an experimental treatment: an application of drugs meant to abort infection in a person who was recently exposed to the virus through unsafe sex. Called post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP, the emergency treatment incorporates the same powerful, toxic drugs commonly given to people with AIDS. Only in this case, the drug regimen is initiated in the hours after suspected exposure, and months before a blood test can verify infection.

headline.main: Emergency Treatment To Stop AIDS Virus

docs.abstract: Growing number of AIDS doctors, frustrated by continued spread of HIV, are trying out an experimental treatment: an application of drugs meant to abort infection in a person who was recently exposed to virus through unsafe sex; emergency treatment, called post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP, incorporates same powerful, toxic drugs commonly given to people with AIDS; photo of Dr Gabriel Torres, who has been using experimental treatment for people who believe they have just been exposed to AIDS virus (M)
